entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Inflation is a sustained rise in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over time, which reduces the purchasing power of money.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Common causes include: (i) Demand-pull factors (aggregate demand exceeds aggregate supply), (ii) Cost-push factors (higher input costs like wages or import prices).

entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Key measures: Monetary policy tightening (raise policy rates, reduce money supply), Fiscal consolidation (reduce deficits), and supply-side steps (remove bottlenecks, import essentials).

entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is the total monetary value of all final goods and services produced within a country's domestic territory during an accounting period (usually a year).

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: difference between nominal gdp and real gdp
entries.a: Nominal GDP is measured at current prices; Real GDP is measured at constant base-year prices. Real GDP removes the effect of price level changes allowing volume comparison over time.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Demand is the quantity of a good that consumers are willing and able to purchase at various prices during a given period, ceteris paribus.

entries.subject: Economics
aliases: what is the law of demand
entries.a: Law of Demand: Other things equal, quantity demanded of a good varies inversely with its price (higher price → lower quantity demanded, and vice versa).

entries.subject: Economics
entries.a: Main determinants: Price of the good, Consumers' income, Prices of related goods (substitutes & complements), Tastes and preferences, Population and demographics, Expectations about future prices/income.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: what causes a shift in demand curve
entries.a: Shifts occur due to non-price factors: changes in income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, population. A change in the good's own price causes movement along the curve, not a shift.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: distinguish between sacrificing ratio and gaining ratio
aliases: difference between sacrificing ratio and gaining ratio
entries.a: Meaning: Sacrifice = Old share − New share (admission); Gain = New share − Old share (retirement/death). Effect: Sacrifice reduces future share; Gain increases future share. Use: Basis for goodwill compensation. When: Sacrifice at admission; Gain at retirement/death. Formulae: Sacrificeᵢ = Oldᵢ − Newᵢ; Gainᵢ = Newᵢ − Oldᵢ.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: why revalue assets and reassess liabilities at retirement or death
entries.a: To ensure fair settlement for the exiting partner: record current values and unrecorded items so the outgoing partner bears/receives the correct share; transfer net revaluation gain/loss to all partners in old PSR.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: why is retiring or deceased partner entitled to share of goodwill
aliases: goodwill entitlement at retirement or death
entries.a: Goodwill is jointly created by all partners; on exit the partner surrenders future benefits arising from goodwill. Therefore, continuing partners (who gain) compensate the outgoing partner for their share of goodwill in the gaining ratio.

entries.subject: Economics
entries.q: methods of computing share of profit for intervening period
aliases: share of profit till date of retirement
profit for the period between last balance sheet and retirement
entries.a: Methods: (i) Last-year profit basis (time apportionment), (ii) Average of past few years’ profit, (iii) Sales-based apportionment. Post via P&L Suspense to outgoing partner; allocate suspense to gaining partners.
